File.Title: Projections of the Ventral Premammillary Nucleus
File.Authors: N.S. CANTERAS, R.B. SIMERLY, AND L.W. SWANSON

Abstract.S: The projections of the ventral premammillary nucleus (PMv) have been examined with the Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL) method in adult male rats.
The results indicate that the nucleus gives rise to two major ascending pathways and a smaller descending pathway.

One large ascending pathway terminates densely in most regions of the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, with the notable exception of the suprachiasmatic, suprachiasmatic preoptic, and median preoptic nuclei.
This pathway is in a position to influence directly many cell groups known to regulate anterior pituitary function.

The second large pathway ascends through the medial zone of the hypothalamus and densely innervates the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus and adjacent basal parts of the lateral hypothalamic area, medial preoptic nucleus, principal nucleus of the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis, ventral lateral septal nucleus, posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala, posterior nucleus, and immediately adjacent regions of the posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala.
It is already known that these regions are major components of the sexually dimorphic circuit, and, interestingly, that they provide the major neural inputs to the PMv.

The smaller descending projection from the PMv seems to innervate preferentially the posterior hypothalamic nucleus, although a small number of fibers appear to end in the tuberomammillary nucleus, supramammillary nucleus, specific regions of the medial mammillary nucleus, interfascicular nucleus, interpeduncular nucleus, periaqueductal gray, dorsal nucleus of the raphe, laterodorsal tegmental nucleus, Barrington's nucleus, and locus coeruleus.

Relatively sparse terminal fields associated with ascending fibers were also observed in the dorsomedial nucleus of the hypothalamus; in the nucleus reuniens, parataenial nucleus, paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus, and mediodorsal nucleus; in the central nucleus of the amygdala, anterodorsal part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala, posterior part of the basomedial nucleus of the amygdala; and in the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of hippocampal field CAI, and the infralimbic and prelimbic areas of the medial prefrontal cortex.

Taken as a whole, the evidence suggests that the PMv receives two major inputs-one from the sexually dimorphic circuit, and the other from the blood in the form of gonadal steroid hormones-and gives rise to two major outputs: one (perhaps feed-forward) to the neuroendocrine (periventricular) zone of the hypothalamus, and the other (perhaps feed-back) to the sexually dimorphic circuit. o 19% wiey-Lis, Inc.

Introduction.S: The ventral premammillary nucleus (PMv) was first recognized by Gurdjian ('27) in the rat as a distinct, compact group of neurons in the medial zone of the hypothalamus, surrounded by the ventromedial, dorsal premammillary, and medial mammillary nuclei.

Previous anatomical observations indicate that the PMv is strongly influenced by areas related to the sexually dimorphic circuit, and as a corollary of this appears to be dominated by sensory inputs relayed from the accessory olfactory bulb by way of the medial and posterior cortical nuclei of the amygdala, as well as by the principal (encapsulated) nucleus of the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis (Krettek and Price, '78; Swanson and Cowan, '79; Post and Mai, '80; Kevetter and Winnans, '81; Luiten et al., '85; Simerly and Swanson, '88; Canteras et al., '92; N.S.

In addition to these neuronal inputs, the PMv may be influenced directly by fluctuating levels of gonadal steroid hormones, since it contains a very high density of neurons that concentrate circulating gonadal steroids (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '75a,b; Stumpf et al., '75), and express high levels of mRNA encoding the androgen receptor, and moderate levels of mRNA encoding the estrogen receptor (Simerly et al., '90).

Previous functional studies indicate that the PMv may be involved in the expression of aggressive behavior (van den Berg et al., '831, thermoregulation (Shiraishi and Mager, '80a,b), and gonadotropin secretion (Beltramino and Taleisnik, '84, '85).
However, just how these and perhaps other responses may be mediated remains largely unknown, partly because the anatomical relationships of the nucleus have yet to be critically analyzed.

Thus, a comprehensive description of the organization of the projections of the PMv should at least facilitate a general understanding of its role in these mechanisms, as well as provide insights into other possible roles played by this structure.

Some information regarding the projections of the PMv can be gleaned from the earlier work of Saper et al. ('76) and Krieger et al. ('791, who reported the results of autoradiographic experiments with 3H-amino acid injections at the level of the PMv.
However, these observations are rather limited because the injection sites always involved surrounding areas.

On the other hand, labeled neurons within the PMv have been reported after injections of retrograde tracers in the septum (Luiten et al., '82; Staiger and Nurnberger, '891, amygdala Weening, '78; Ottersen, '80; Russchen, '82; Luiten et al., '85; Volz et al., '901, thalamus (Herkenham, '78; Cornwall and Phillipson, '88; Chen and Su, 'go), hypothalamus (Shiosaka et al., '80; Kita and Oomura, '82; Sawchenko and Swanson, '83; Chiba and Murata, '85; Simerly and Swanson, '86; Fahrbach et al., '891, and brainstem (Contestabile and Flumerfelt, '81; Morrell et al., '81; Satoh and Fibiger, '86).

In the present report we describe the results of a series of pathway-tracing experiments in which the anterogradely transported lectin, Phaseolus uulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL), was injected into the PMv, and the distribution of labeled axons throughout the forebrain and brainstem was determined.
As is now well known, this method has a number of advantages.
It is very sensitive, does not appear to label fibers-of-passage, and has very clear injection sites since the dendrites and somata of neurons that give rise to labeled projections are filled.

In addition, projections are labeled with the clarity of a Golgi impregnation, thus allowing the identification of terminal boutons and varicosities along axons as well as at their ends (see Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84; Wouterlood and Groenewegen, '85; Canteras et al., '92).
The results of the present report are compared with our observations on the projections of the nearby ventromedial and dorsal premammillary nuclei (Canteras and Swanson, '92b).
A preliminary account of this work has been presented elsewhere (Canteras et al., '90).

Methods.S: Ten adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (275-340 g) received an injection of PHAL (Vector Laboratories) into the region of the ventral premammillary nucleus.

Each animal was anesthetized with tribromoethanol (0.25 g/kg b.w., dissolved in 9O:lO saline/ethanol, v/v), and a single iontophoretic injection of a 2.5% solution of PHAL in 0.01 M sodium phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4) was made through a stereotaxically positioned glass micropipette (tip diameter 10 pm) by applying a +4 pA current pulsed at 7-second intervals, provided by a constant-current source (Midgard Electronics, model CS3), for a period of 15 minutes.
Postinjection survival times for all experiments ranged from 14 to 16 days.
The animals were perfused and the brains were processed according to procedures described in detail elsewhere (Canteras et al., '92).

Briefly, each animal was deeply anesthetized with tribromoethanol and perfused transcardially with a solution of 4.0% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M sodium borate buffer at pH 9.5; the brains were removed immediately and postfixed overnight in the same fixative containing 10% sucrose.

Three series of 30-pm-thick frozen sections were cut in the frontal plane on a sliding microtome and collected at the following frequencies: one-in-ten through the olfactory bulbs and forebrain rostral to the vascular organ of the lamina terminalis, one-in-four through the hypothalamus and rostral half of the midbrain, and one-in-ten through the caudal midbrain and hindbrain.
Additional sections were collected through levels containing the PMv and "quickstained" for confirmation of the injection site location (see Simerly and Swanson, '88).
One complete series of sections was processed for immunohistochemistry with an antiserum directed against PHAL (Dako Laboratories) at a dilution of 1: 1,000.

The antigen-antibody complex was localized by using a variation of the avidin-biotin complex system (ABC; Hsu and Raine, '81; Hsu et al., '811, with a commercially available kit (ABC Elite Kit, Vector Laboratories).
The sections were mounted on gelatin-coated slides, and treated with osmium tetroxide to enhance visibility of the reaction product.
Slides were then dehydrated and coverslipped with DPX.
An adjacent series was always stained with thionin to serve as a reference series for cytoarchitectonic purposes.
Sections were examined with a Leitz Laborlux D microscope with both brightand darkfield illumination.

PHALlabeled cells in the injection sites, as well as the distribution of the anterogradely labeled fibers, were plotted with the aid of a camera lucida on maps prepared from the adjacent Nissl-stained sections.
For the purposes of illustration, the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers was transposed onto a series of standard drawings of the rat brain (Swanson, '92).

Finally, it should be noted that we generated six experiments with an iontophoretic deposit of the retrograde tracer fluorogold (Schmued and Fallon, '86) centered in the PMv, using procedures described in detail elsewhere (Canteras et al., '92).
These experiments were carried out to determine possible sources of afferents to the PMv.

However, since the results almost entirely confirmed information in the literature, we have chosen not to describe these results, although they are occasionally referred to in the Discussion, where they help to clarify an issue or add a seemingly minor detail.

Results.S: The parameters used for iontophoretic injections described above resulted in very discrete injection sites, usually with hundreds of neurons that were clearly labeled with PHAL.

TTE.S: As shown in Figure 1, five experiments labeled neurons that were fairly confined to the PMv.
Although a few neurons outside the limits of the PMv were labeled in each case, in all of these experiments a very similar pattern of anterogradely labeled fibers was observed.
Experiment PMv-8 (Figs. 2 and 3) was chosen as a prototype to illustrate our results, since the injection here labeled the most extensive population of cells in the PMv.

Labeled axons from the PMv may be divided into an ascending group that innervates targets rostral to the nucleus in the diencephalon and telencephalon, and a much smaller descending group that ends in the brainstem central gray.
Ascending projections
Hypothalamus.

The greater part of the labeled fibers that arise from injection sites in the PMv course rostrally through the periventricular and medial zones of the hypothalamus, while a smaller group of axons was also observed coursing through the medial forebrain bundle.
From the injection site in experiment PMv-8 (Fig. 3K,L), a rather large number of fibers course medially and then rostrally to ascend within the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus.

The density of fibers and terminal boutons within this zone indicates that the PMv supplies relatively strong inputs to all parts of the periventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus, as well as the related arcuate and paraventricular nuclei.
Within the arcuate nucleus, we observed a terminal field that was particularly dense laterally (Figs. 3 H 4 , 4E).
It is important to note that, in spite of massive inputs to nearby areas, the median eminence was virtually free of anterograde labeling (Figs. 3H4, 4E).

Within the paraventricular nucleus, labeled fibers and terminal boutons were particularly numerous in the periventricular and anterior parvicellular parts, whereas the rest of the parvicellular division, as well as the anterior part of the magnocellular division, appears to receive a sparser innervation (Figs. 3F-I, 4D).

Only an occasional labeled fiber was observed in the posterior part of the magnocellular division or in the supraoptic nucleus (see Swanson and Simmons, '89, for subdivision of the paraventricular nucleus).

Rostrally, at the level of the preoptic region, axons from the PMv coursing through the periventricular zone provide a remarkably dense terminal field within the anteroventral periventricular nucleus (Figs. 3C,D, 4A).
Some of these fibers continue farther rostrally to end in a region just lateral to the vascular organ of the lamina terminalis.

Thus, the PMv projects densely to most regions within the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus; curious~y, the Only in this 'One that do not Seem to receive a significant input are the suprachiasmatic, suprachiasmatic preoptic, and median preoptic nuclei (Fig. 3C-G).
Another massive contingent of labeled fibers ascends from the injection site through the medial zone of the hypothalamus.

Just rostral to the PMv, these fibers give rise to an exceedingly dense terminal field that fills the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus and ventrally adjacent parts of the basal lateral hypothalamic area (Fig. 35).

The dorsomedial and central parts of ventromedial nucleus were virtually free of anterograde labeling, although the cell-poor zone surrounding dorsal aspects of the nucleus appears to receive a moderate number of labeled axons (Fig. 3H-J).
At this level, some labeled fibers continue dorsally to end in the dorsomedial nucleus, particularly medially near the periventricular zone (Fig. 35).
Toward the rostral end of the tuberal region, most of the fibers coursing through the medial zone tend to display few branches and terminal boutons, appearing more like fibers-of-passage (Fig. 3H,I).

These axons continue rostrally through the anterior hypothalamic area (Fig. 3G-I), where they also give rise to few terminal boutons, to reach the medial preoptic area, which (in contrast) is filled by a dense plexus of highly branched axons displaying an overwhelming number of terminal boutons (Fig. 3E,F).

Within this area, the medial preoptic nucleus receives a particularly dense input that is somewhat more dense in the medial as compared to the lateral part and is very sparse in the central part (Figs. 3E,F, 4B).
The anterodorsal and anteroventral preoptic nuclei, as well as the parastrial nucleus, appear to receive only a very sparse input from the PMv (Fig. 3C-E).
A small group of fibers from the PMv courses dorsally and then laterally to ascend through the dorsal half of the medial forebrain bundle (Fig. 3F-L).
As they travel through the lateral hypothalamic area, very few terminal boutons can be seen on these axons.

At the level of the anterior hypothalamic area, some of these fibers turn medially, dorsal to the descending column of the fornix, and provide a relatively sparse input to rostral parts of the zona incerta and ventral parts of the nucleus reuniens, in a region dorsal to the paraventricular nucleus (Fig. 3G,H).

At the rostral end of the lateral hypothalamic area, the remaining fibers in this pathway enter caudal regions of the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis and the substantia innominata, joining a larger group of fibers from the PMv that leaves the medial preoptic area at this level (Fig. 3F), as described below.
Thalamus.
A moderate number of labeled fibers from the PMv that ascend through the hypothalamus take a dorsal course to provide inputs to several parts of the thalamus.

The paraventricular nucleus receives a moderate plexus of fibers that also appears to extend somewhat to adjacent parts of the paratenial nucleus and the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus (Fig. 3F-L).
In addition, we observed sparse anterograde labeling throughout the length of the nucleus reuniens; these fibers were especially common in ventral regions of the nucleus (Fig. 3G-J).
Septum.

A group of fibers from the PMv that ascends through the medial zone, and perhaps, to a much lesser extent, through the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus appears to provide massive inputs to the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis (BST), the lateral septal nucleus, and certain parts of the amygdala.

At preoptic levels these axons leave the medial zone of the hypothalamus, taking either a dorsolateral route toward caudal regions of the BST (Fig. 3E,F) or a dorsal route rostral to the anterior commissure (Fig. 30.

Parts of the posterior division of the BST (see Ju and Swanson, '89 for subdivision of the BST) are filled with a dense plexus of fibers, and at this level some labeled fibers enter the stria terminalis or, to a much lesser extent, the substantia innominata (ansa peduncularis) to gain access to the amygdala (Fig. 3E,F).

Within the posterior division of the BST, the labeled fibers running through the interfascicular and transverse nuclei display many fewer ramifications and terminal boutons as compared to axons lying more medially within the principal nucleus, where a rather dense terminal field was observed, particularly around the periphery of the nucleus (Figs. 3E,F, 4C).

Within the anterior division of the BST, labeled fibers are widely distributed throughout the anterodorsal and anteroventral areas, while obviously tending to avoid the anterolateral area (Fig. 3C-E).

Many fibers from the PMv also end in the lateral septal nucleus, where they form a particularly dense terminal field in the caudal two-thirds of the ventral part and adjacent regions of the intermediate part (Fig. 3B-D).
At more rostral levels, considerably fewer labeled axons and terminal boutons were found, and these were located primarily within the intermediate part of the nucleus (Fig. 3B).
Prefrontal cortex.
A few labeled fibers continue rostrally from the lateral septal nucleus and appear to end in the infralimbic and prelimbic areas (Fig. 3A).

These axons, which display a few varicosities and terminal boutons, do not form a strikingly laminar input to these regions of the medial prefrontal cortex, and labeled fibers were not observed in other nearby parts of the cortical mantle.
Amygdala.
This part of the telencephalon receives a very dense input from the PMv.

Labeled fibers from the injection site reach the amygdala primarily by way of the stria terminalis, although a few axons also appear to run through the lateral hypothalamic area and the substantia innominata in the ansa peduncularis.

The medial part, and ventral regions of the capsular part, of the central nucleus, as well as the anterodorsal part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala, appear to receive moderate inputs from the PMv, which at these levels also seems to provide a much sparser input to adjacent regions such as the intercalated nuclei and the anterior part of the basomedial nucleus (Fig. 3G-I).

At caudal levels of the amygdala (for parcellation see Canteras et al., '921, the PMv gives rise to very dense projections to the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus, to the posterior nucleus, and to adjacent regions of the posterior cortical nucleus (Fig. 3J-M).
Labeled fibers from the PMv form a particularly dense terminal field in deeper parts of the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus (Fig. 35).
Specifically, these fibers appear to innervate selectively a distinct rod-shaped cell aggregate in deeper parts of the nucleus.

As pointed out elsewhere, the PMv represents by far the main source of afferent fibers to the posterior nucleus (Canteras et al., '921, which, in all of the experiments analyzed in the present study, is filled with a remarkably dense plexus of fibers that spreads to include adjacent deep parts and medialmost regions of the molecular layer of the posterior cortical nucleus (Figs. 3K-M, 4F).

At these levels of the amygdala we also observed a smaller number of labeled fibers that appear to end in the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus and the posterior part of the basolateral nucleus (Fig. 3J-M).
Hippoearnpal formation.
At the caudal pole of the amygdala, a moderate number of labeled axons take a medial course to end in the ventral tip of the subiculum and adjacent parts of hippocampal field CAI (Fig. 3L-N).
A few labeled axons could also be followed to area TK.
(Fig. 3M,N), the ventral part of the medial entorhinal area (Fig. 3N, area 28M' of Haug, '761, and ventral regions of the lateral entorhinal area (not illustrated).
Descending projections
The descending projections of the PMv are considerably less extensive than the ascending projections.
From the injection site, labeled fibers travel dorsally to enter the posterior hypothalamic nucleus.
The majority of these fibers course dorsally, just rostra1 to the dorsal premammillary nucleus; only a few axons with very sparse terminal boutons pass through this nucleus (Fig. 3K,L).

Labeled fibers give rise to a rather dense terminal field in ventral parts of the posterior hypothalamic nucleus (Fig. 3K,L), and at least some of them continue on caudally either toward the mammillary complex or into the periaqueductal gray.

In the mammillary complex, the PMv provides a sparse projection to the medial and lateral parts of the supramammillary nucleus and to the cell-poor zone that surrounds the medial mammillary nucleus (Fig. 3M,N).
A very few of these fibers continue on to end in the interfascicular and interpeduncular nuclei and perhaps the ventral tegmental area (Fig. 3N,O).
In addition, at caudal levels of the PMv, a sparse number of labeled fibers were also observed projecting to the ventral part of the tuberomammillary nucleus (Fig. 3L).
Labeled fibers in the midbrain periventricular system appear to provide inputs primarily to ventrolateral parts of the periaqueductal gray (Fig. 30,P).
In addition, a few labeled axons also appear to innervate the dorsal nucleus of the raphe and the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (Fig. 30,P).
At still more caudal levels, the periventricular fibers course chiefly through lateral parts of the pontine central gray, near the ependymal wall of the fourth ventricle (Fig. 3Q-S).
A very few of these fibers arch laterally to end in the lateral part of the parabrachial nucleus (Fig. 3Q,R).

Although labeled fibers were observed only rarely within the nuclear borders of the locus coeruleus (Fig. 3S), some labeled fibers and terminal boutons were observed immediately rostral to it; these fibers appear to innervate the so-called Barrington's nucleus (Fig. 3R), which is the most caudal structure to receive significant projections from the PMv.
Crossed projections
In general, the contralateral projection is a mirror image of the ipsilateral projection, but much less dense.
In the forebrain, labeled fibers appear to cross the midline through the supraoptic commissures and the supramammillary decussation.
It is important to point out here that the latter fibers, in addition to other contralateral targets, provide a moderate projection to the contralateral PMv.

Results.S: Curiously, the density of contralateral labeled fibers is relatively greater in the midbrain and pons than in the forebrain.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The major conclusion that can be drawn from the experiments reported here is that the PMv supplies a dense input to the medial and periventricular zones of the hypothalamus, to the septal region, and to the amygdala.

In view of the advantages of the PHAL method referred to in the Introduction, and the fact that there is little disagreement as to the location and boundaries of the PMv, our description of its projections would appear to be rather reliable.

Nevertheless, our results are limited in a number of ways, since, for example, they do not address the issue of whether the projections of the PMv arise from a homogeneous population of cells or whether they arise from multiple cell types, and they do not address the issue of neurotransmitter specificity.
Projections of the PMv
Because the projections of the PMv itself have never been examined with anterograde tracing methods, our discussion of the literature must rely primarily on earlier retrograde tracer studies.

Our results indicate that the great majority of fibers from the PMv take a rostral course, through both the periventricular and medial zones of the hypothalamus, whereas much smaller groups of axons ascend through the medial forebrain bundle, or descend through caudal parts of the hypothalamus and central gray.

The medialmost projections from the PMv ascend through the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, which is densely innervated throughout, except for the suprachiasmatic, suprachiasmatic preoptic, and median preoptic nuclei, where virtually no labeled fibers were observed.

Inputs to the paraventricular nucleus from the PMv have been identified previously with retrograde tracers (Sawchenko and Swanson, '831, and Luiten et al. ('87) reported such a projection with the PHAL, method, although the terminal field they described differs substantially from our observations.

They illustrate (their Fig. 12; Luiten et al., '87) a moderate terminal field centered in the medial parvicellular part of the paraventricular nucleus after an injection site that appears to involve the rostral tip of the PMv.
All of our experiments that involved the PMv, including the region illustrated for their injection site, labeled a massive terminal field in the periventricular zone of the paraventricular nucleus.
The reason for this discrepancy is not apparent.

Fibers from the PMv that ascend through the medial zone of the hypothalamus give rise to a particularly dense projection to the ventrolateral part of the ventromedial nucleus and surrounding parts of the basal lateral hypothalamic area, as well as to the medial preoptic nucleus, as suggested by earlier retrograde tracer studies (Kita and Oomura, '82; Chiba and Murata, '85; Simerly and Swanson, '86; Fahrbach et al., '89).

A somewhat weaker projection was found to the dorsomedial nucleus, and to the cell-poor region surrounding the dorsomedial subdivision of the ventromedial nucleus; the PMv does not appear to provide a substantial input to the cellular "core" regions of the dorsomedial and central parts of the ventromedial nucleus, or to cell groups in the anterior hypothalamic area.
A projection from the PMv to the dorsomedial nucleus was reported by Kita and Oomura ('82) using retrograde tracer methods.

Previous retrograde and anterograde studies suggested that a projection from the PMv travels through the medial forebrain bundle (Shiosaka et al., '80; Veening et al., '821, and here we were able to confirm that a small number of such fibers course through the dorsal half of the medial forebrain bundle, where they give rise to very few terminal boutons and have the appearance of fibers-of-passage.

These axons seem to provide a sparse input to rostral parts of the zona incerta and the ventral part of the nucleus reuniens, while at more rostral levels the remaining fibers enter the posterior subdivision of the BST and the substantia innominata.

The nucleus reuniens also seems to receive an input from fibers ascending from the injection site through the medial and periventricular zones of the hypothalamus, fibers that also provide a rather substantial input to the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus.

Evidence for a projection from the PMv to these thalamic nuclei was also reported in earlier retrograde tracer studies (Herkenham, '78; Cornwall and Phillipson, '88; Chen and A large group of fibers from the PMv ascending mainly through the medial zone of the hypothalamus ultimately ends in the BST, lateral septal nucleus, and amygdala.
Within the BST, axons from the PMv give rise to a particularly dense terminal field in the principal nucleus.

Weller and Smith ('82) reported the presence of retrogradely labeled cells in the premammillary region after injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) in the BST, although they did not state that these cells were within the PMv itself.

Inputs to the lateral septal nucleus were also suggested in previous retrograde tracer studies (Luiten et al., '82; Staiger and Nurnberger, '891, and have been confirmed more directly here; we observed a particularly dense projection to the caudal two-thirds of the ventral part, and adjacent regions of the intermediate part, of this nucleus.
A few axons from the PMv continue through the rostral pole of the lateral septal nucleus to end in the infralimbic and prelimbic areas of the medial prefrontal cortex.
The majority of fibers from the PMv that project to the amygdala travel through the stria terminalis, whereas only a few course through the ansa peduncularis.

Within the amygdala, these fibers provide a massive input to the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus, to the posterior nucleus, and to immediately adjacent regions of the posterior cortical nucleus, as well as a sparser input to other parts of the amygdala, including the medial and capsular parts of the central nucleus, and the anterodorsal part of the medial nucleus.

Tracer injections centered in (but not necessarily restricted to) each of the above-mentioned parts of the amygdala retrogradely label cells in the vicinity of the PMv (Veening, '78; Ottersen, '80; Russchen, '82; Luiten et al., '85; Volz et al., '90).

Furthermore, recent observations using fluorogold as a retrograde tracer indicate that the PMv is by far the main source of projections to the posterior nucleus of the amygdala (Canteras et al., '92).
Finally, ascending fibers from the PMv also end in limited parts of the cortex adjacent to the amygdala, particularly in the ventral tip of the subiculum and adjacent parts of hippocampal field CAI.

Descending projections from the PMv give rise to a substantial input to ventral regions of the posterior hypothalamic nucleus and a few axons continue on to the mammillary complex and to the midbrain periventricular system.

Within the mammillary complex, the PMv appears to innervate the supramammillary nucleus and the cell-poor zone surrounding the medial mammillary nucleus, with a very few fibers continuing even farther to end in the interfascicular and interpeduncular nuclei.
A sparse projection from the PMv to the interpeduncular nucleus was suggested by Contestabile and Flumerfelt ('81) using HRP as a retrograde tracer.
The fibers coursing through the midbrain periventricular system form a distinct terminal field in ventrolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray.
At this level, a somewhat weaker input was also found to the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus and the dorsal nucleus of the raphe.

In agreement with our observations, injections of retrograde tracers in the periaqueductal gray (Morrell et al., '811, and in the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (Satoh and Fibiger, '861, labeled only a few cells within the PMv.
At pontine levels, we observed a small number of fibers coursing caudally, near the wall of the fourth ventricle.
These axons provide a distinctive innervation to a region just rostral to the locus coeruleus that is thought to correspond to Barrington's nucleus, as discussed further below.
Finally, occasional PHAL-labeled fibers were observed within the boundaries of the locus coeruleus, which appears to be the caudalmost target of efferents from the PMv.
It may be of interest at this point to summarize what little is known about possible neurotransmitters utilized by the pathways just described.
Previous immunohistochemical studies have provided some information about neuropeptides that may be synthesized by neurons of the PMv.

Thus, it has been shown that at least some PMv neurons may express met-enkephalin (Wamsley et al., '80; Abe et al., '871, substance P (Tsuruo et al., '84; Akesson and Micevych, '881, atrial natriuretic peptide (Jacobowitz et al., '85; Standaert et al., '86; Bidmon et al., 'go), and galanin (Skofitsch and Jacobowitz, '85).
Clearly, a great deal remains to be learned about neurotransmission in the terminal fields established by the PMv.
In addition to these peptides, other neurotransmitters are likely to be utilized by neurons located within the PMv, although further studies are needed to clarify this issue.
Comparison between projections of the PMv and adjacent nuclei in the medial hypothalamus As mentioned in the Introduction, the PMv lies in the
medial zone of the hypothalamus, just caudal to the ventromedial nucleus, and at more caudal levels it lies just ventral to the dorsal premammillary nucleus.
There are two major reasons for comparing what we now know about the projections from these three regions.
First, since all of our PHAL injection sites labeled at least a few neurons outside the limits of the PMv, it is important to consider the pattern of efferents from adjacent cell groups.
Second, it is clearly important to determine whether the PMv plays a unique role in circuits associated with the caudal hypothalamus.

The following comparisons are based on the work of Saper et al. ('76), Krieger et al. ('791, and our own unpublished observations (with the PHAL method) for the ventromedial nucleus, and our paper on the dorsal premammillary nucleus (Canteras and Swanson, '92b).

To begin with, in contrast to the PMv, the ventromedial nucleus provides a massive input to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, but a much less dense projection to nuclei within the periventricular zone.

In addition, we have observed in our PHAL experiments that the projection from the ventromedial nucleus to the preoptic region, which arises chiefly from cell bodies in the ventrolateral subdivision (see Simerly and Swanson, '86), is mainly directed toward the lateral subdivision of the medial preoptic nucleus, in contrast to the medial part of this nucleus, which receives a very small input.
It will be recalled that the PMv projects densely to both the medial and lateral parts of the medial preoptic nucleus, with slightly more fibers in the medial part.

Similarly, the PMv provides a strong input to the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, whereas only a few labeled fibers are found in this structure following injections of PHAL centered in the ventromedial nucleus.

Like the PMv, a group of fibers from the ventromedial nucleus gives rise to a dense terminal field in the BST that tends to avoid the principal nucleus, unlike inputs from the PMv that end heavily within the principal nucleus.

Furthermore, cells in the ventromedial nucleus project less densely to the septum, where inputs tend to be more uniformly distributed in the ventral and intermediate parts of the lateral septal nucleus, than is the case for inputs from the PMv.
There are remarkable differences between the projections of the ventromedial nucleus and the PMv to the amygdala.
Thus, fibers arising in the ventromedial nucleus project to the amygdala by way of the ansa peduncularis and end primarily in the central nucleus and in the lateral nucleus.
In contrast, most projections from the PMv to the amygdala course through the stria terminalis and end primarily in the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus and in the posterior nucleus.

Finally, the descending projections from the ventromedial nucleus to the brainstem appear to be more extensive than those from the PMv and give rise to particularly dense inputs to the central gray and the peripenduncular nucleus.

Our recent findings on the projections of the dorsal premammillary nucleus (PMd) using the PHAL, method clearly indicate that the overall pattern of efferents arising from this nucleus is quite distinct from that of the PMv and the ventromedial nucleus (Canteras and Swanson, '92b).
Thus, the PMd gives rise to a characteristic projection to the ventral part of the anteromedial nucleus of the thalamus, as well as dense projections to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus.

In contrast to the PMv, only a few axons from the PMd innervate the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, the medial preoptic area, the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis, the septum, and the amygdala.
Finally, the PMd innervates rather densely a characteristic dorsolatera1 zone of the periaqueductal gray.
Inputs to the PMv

Since we have characterized the distribution of projections from the PMv, and compared the pattern of projections from this nucleus with those arising from surrounding regions in the medial zone of the hypothalamus, it is now appropriate to review what is known about the afferent control of the PMv.

As mentioned in the Introduction, the PMv is thought to receive dense inputs from the medial nucleus of the amygdala (especially its posterodorsal part), the posterior nucleus and adjacent deep regions of the posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala, the principal nucleus of the BST, and the medial preoptic nucleus (particularly from the central part and adjacent regions of the medial part) (Krettek and Price, '78; Swanson and Cowan, '79; Post and Mai, '80; Kevetter and Winnans, '81; Luiten et al., '85; Simerly and Swanson, '88; Canteras et al., '92; N.S.
Canteras, R.B.
Simerly, and L.W.
Swanson, unpublished observations; see Materials and Methods).

Perhaps the most obvious features common to all of the sources of afferents to the PMv just listed is that they are in a position to relay information from the vomeronasal organ (for references see Canteras et al., '92).

Other classes of sensory information may well reach the PMv by way of the ventral subiculum and ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus (see Swanson et al., '871, where we found labeled cells after fluorogold deposits in the region of the PMv, although only the projection from the ventral subiculum has been reported with anterograde tracing methods (Swanson and Cowan, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78; Canteras and Swanson, '92a).

The PMv may also receive relatively sparse inputs from the infralimbic area (Brittain, '88; Hurley et al., '91), the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus of the amygdala (Krettek and Price, '78), and the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus (N.S.
Canteras, R.B.
Simerly, and L.W.
Swanson, unpublished observations).

Finally, our fluorogold experiments revealed at least a few labeled cells in other areas of the forebrain and brainstem for which anterograde tracing data are not available, including area TR, the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus, the periaqueductal gray, the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus, the dorsal nucleus of the raphe, the nucleus incertus, and the locus coeruleus.

Recently, it has been suggested (Perez-Clause11 et al., '89) that the massive projection from posterior nucleus of the amygdala to the PMv contains high levels of zinc, which are presumably associated with pools of excitatory amino acid neurotransmitters (Frederickson and Danscher, '90).

In addition, the PMv receives a substantial number of fibers that cross-react with antisera to met-enkephalin (Abe et al., '87), atrial natriuretic peptide (Standaert et al., '861, and neuropeptide Y (DeQuidt et al., '90).

The distribution of neuropeptide Y-immunoreactive axons is commonly rather similar to that of fibers stained with antisera to tyrosine hydroxylase and dopamine-P-hydroxylase (see Sawchenko et al., '85; Simerly et al., '86).
This does not seem to be the case in the region of the PMv, however, where very few axons containing these catecholamine-synthesizing enzymes have been identified (Swanson and Hartman, '75).
The PMv also appears to receive sparse serotonergic and cholinergic inputs (Steinbusch, '81; Rao et al., '87).

Further studies that combine retrograde tracing with immunohistochemistry are needed to determine the location of cell bodies that give rise to each of these neurochemically defined inputs to the PMv.

For the sake of completeness, it should be noted that high concentrations of NK3 receptors, which apparently bind specifically neurokinin B (NKB), have been reported in the PMv (Mussap and Burcher, '90).

However, a precise "matching" of NK3 binding sites to NKB-immunoreactive terminals, as well as the location of cell bodies that synthesize this peptide, is not possible at this time due to the absence of specific NKB antibodies (see Mussap and Burcher, '90).

In addition to these neural inputs, the PMv may be influenced directly by fluctuating levels of gonadal steroid hormones, since it contains a very high density of neurons that concentrate estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '75a,b; Stumpf et al., '751, and mRNAs encoding the androgen and estrogen receptors are expressed at relatively high levels in the PMv (Simerly et al., '90).

In general, there appears to be a considerable degree of overlap between the cells that concentrate each of these gonadal steroids, although the extent to which individual neurons express more than one steroid hormone receptor is unclear.

Michael et al. ('89) have suggested that, in male macaques, most of the testosterone that is taken up by neurons in the PMv is not converted to estradiol, whereas in the rat, only a small population of neurons within the PMv does not seem to aromatize androgen to estrogen (Sheridan, '79).

Considering the evidence that these hormones may regulate cellular levels of neuropeptides (for references see Simerly et al., '901, it will be of interest to characterize the neurotransmitterspecificity of the PMv neurons that expresses androgen andlor estrogen receptors, and to determine whether gonadal steroids influence their rate of synthesis.

It is also important to point out that the strongest projections from the PMv end in nuclei that also contain high densities of gonadal steroid-concentrating neurons (PfafF and Keiner, '73; Sar and Stumpf, '75a,b; Stumpf et al., '751, express mRNAs encoding the androgen and/or estrogen receptors (Simerly et al., '901, and display structural sexual dimorphisms (see for references see Simerly and Swanson, '88).
Furthermore, almost all these regions innervate densely the PMv.
These remarkable hodological relationships between the PMv and the sexually dimorphic cell groups suggests that the PMv plays an important role in the function of this neuronal network.

In addition, it has been shown that the PMv itself may be sexually dimorphic with respect to the number of tachykinin-immunoreactive cells, which are more numerous in males (Akesson and Micevych, '91).
We have not in the present study examined the projections of the PMv in female animals.

However, the results of previous anatomical studies in the medial preoptic nucleus and elsewhere suggests that the sexually dimorphic circuit is qualitatively similar in both sexes, while presenting quantitative differences within particular terminal fields (see Simerly and Swanson, '88).
Functional implications

At the most basic level, the PMv appears to integrate neuronal influences from other forebrain regions, particularly those related to the sexually dimorphic circuit, receiving but sparse direct inputs from other centers in the brainstem.

Remarkably, with the exception of the ventral subiculum and adjacent parts of hippocampal field CAI (and the central part of the medial preoptic nucleus), the main sources of projections to the PMv in turn receive a massive input from the PMv.

In addition, the PMv provides massive unidirectional projections to most parts of the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, which is known to be the major central regulator of anterior pituitary function.

In short, the PMv establishes massive bidirectional connections with the sexually dimorphic circuit, and projects massively to the neuroendocrine zone of the hypothalamus, in addition to expressing high levels of gonadal steroid hormone receptors (see Fig. 5).

Electrolytic lesions in the region of the PMv reportedly induce a premature onset of the proestrous surge of luteinizing hormone (LH), while electrochemical stimulation applied to the nucleus at noon on the day of proestrus prevented ovulation and the preovulatory surge of LH (Beltramino and Taleisnik, '84).
The PMv has also been implicated in the regulation of LH secretion by pheromonal stimuli (Beltramino and Taleisnik, '85).

Our results indicate that the PMv may not provide a substantial direct input to neurons that express gonadotropin-releasing hormone (Barry, '79; King et al., '821, although it may indirectly influence the secretion of LH or follicle-stimulating hormone by way of its massive inputs to the anteroventral periventricular nucleus of the preoptic region and the arcuate nucleus, which are thought to be involved in the regulation of these hormones (Wiegand and Terasawa, '82; Kalra and Kalra, '83).

Our results also suggest that the PMv may influence the secretion of prolactin and growth hormone as well, through its dense projections to the arcuate nucleus, where the majority of neurosecretory cells containing dopamine (see Bjorklund and Lindvall, '84) and growth hormone-releasing hormone (Sawchenko and Swanson, '90) are found.
Furthermore, the PMv projects massively to the periventricular region (the anterior periventricular nucleus) that contains the majority of neurosecretory somatostatin cells (see Swanson, '87).

Other parvicellular neurosecretory regions of the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus appear to be considerably less densely innervated and very few axons from the PMv are associated with magnocellular neurosecretory neurons.

Marked hypothermic responses have been reported after the injection of low concentrations of 2-deoxy-d-glucose (2-DG) into the region of the PMv, and it has been suggested that this effect is related in some way to vagal stimulation and subsequent lowering of peripheral heat production (Shiraishi and Mager, '80a,b).

The PMv does not appear to provide direct inputs to preganglionic autonomic neurons, but does project to cell groups that are known to project in turn to both sympathetic and parasympathetic preganglionic cell groups.

Thus, the PMv provides direct inputs to the posterior hypothalamic nucleus and the retrochiasmatic area, as well as to the tuberal zone of the hypothalamus, all of which contain at least a few neurons that project to the dorsal vagal complex and/or the spinal cord, presumably to the intermediolateral cell column; however, it is not clear where in the spinal cord most of these hypothalamic neurons end, and the density of cells that project to lower autonomic centers in these hypothalamic regions is quite low (see Swanson, '87, for review).

The dorsal parvicellular part of the paraventricular nucleus, which projects preferentially to preganglionic sympathetic neurons in the spinal cord, as well as the ventral medial parvicellular part of the nucleus, which projects more or less equally to the dorsal vagal complex and to the spinal cord (see Swanson and Sawchenko, '831, also receives a sparse projection from the PMv.

In addition, the PMv sends rather substantial projections to lateral regions of the BST and also less dense inputs to the medial part of the central nucleus of the amygdala, both of which are known to provide direct, massive inputs to the dorsal vagal complex (Sofroniew, '83; Holstege et al., '85; see Price et al., '87 for reviews).

A final way that the PMv may influence parasympathetic outflow is via a direct projection to Barrington's nucleus, which provides a direct input to the region of sacral parasympathetic preganglionic neurons (Loewy et al., '791, and appears to correspond to the "micturition reflex center" in the dorsolateral pontine tegmentum that was described by Barrington (see Satoh et al., '78).

It is important to point out here that, apart from all of these regions that may provide direct inputs to autonomic cell groups, the PMv gives rise to a very dense projection to the medial preoptic nucleus, which is thought to provide an important influence on a variety of responses that involve the autonomic nervous system (see Simerly and Swanson, '88 for review).

It has also been suggested that the PMv plays a role in central mechanisms that underlie aggressive behavior, in view of the fact that small bilateral electrolytic lesions in the region of this nucleus led to marked increases in attack behavior (van den Berg et al., '83).

Perhaps this result should not be surprising in view of strong bidirectional connections between the PMv and several regions thought to be involved in the control of antagonistic behavior, including the medial nucleus of the amygdala, the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis, the lateral septa1 nucleus, and the medial preoptic nucleus (see Luiten et al., '85; Swanson, '87).

Considering the possible involvement of the PMv in the expression of aggressive behavior, it is important to recall that thresholds for the activation of this type of behavior are modulated by circulating levels of gonadal steroid hormones (see Floody and Pfaff, '74).

Finally, the anatomical results presented here strongly imply that the PMv is involved in at least some aspects of reproductive physiology and behavior, although clearly, further work is needed to explore this possibility.
